reviews.author: Happypig375
reviews.title: Guide on how to credit transfer LANG1002 and LANG1003 using IELTS as an example
reviews.comment_content:
Quick summary from other reviews:
Tasks include:
- two writing tasks, the first one being a paragraph to prepare for the second one: a 600 to 800 word essay on 'Game Changer'
- two 3 to 5 minute self-recorded videos of you giving a speech to inspire high school students and describe the game changer respectively
- two quizzes on 40 (list 1) and 120 (list 1 to 3) vocabularies respectively from the textbook

And this is just LANG1002. Next term you will take LANG1003 which is an extension of this course. Do you really want to do all of this when you can get 6 easy credits by transferring?

Well you may also learn APA citation from the library section but come on, you can just find APA citation generators online.
reviews.comment_teaching: Depending on the instructor, you will either be cared with love and be given great support or be ignored and have your grade killed.
reviews.comment_grading:
Just trust your peers and recognize that this is a subjective course... LANG1002 and LANG1003 are extremely difficult to swap so even when you know the instructor is a killer you can't escape from it.

Just take a look at grindingalways's review: So many 7s but still not A+!

Even worse, you won't even know who is assigned to you! You can only know if a killer is assigned to you after the course has started! (See attachment LANG1002A.png)
reviews.comment_workload:
[Here is the guide on credit transfer]
I only have a 5 in DSE English but managed to score a 7.5 in IELTS.
So here are the steps:
1. Visit https://crtran.ust.hk/exam_redirect
2. Check the requirements of credit transfer. Here I use IELTS for example: Grade of score needed for credit transfer is 7.0 or above (with no subscore lower than 6.5) and also the footnote declares that "To be valid for credit transfer, a grade or score must have been obtained in the two
years before a student applied for admission to HKUST, i.e. if the studentâ€™s application is
dated 1st March 2019, the grade or score must have been obtained in the period 1st March 2017-1st March 2019."
3. Follow https://crtran.ust.hk/application_procedure but do not use the "Credit Transfer System for Undergraduate Students" (https://w5.ab.ust.hk/jsct/ct_stdt_appl) because you will not find public examinations like IELTS there, only university names as this system is for people who have studied in other universities before. However, you should take note of "Official transcript or examination certificate" and "Course/subject information" (LANG1002 and LANG1003).
4. Send an email to crtran@ust.hk and remember to attach a copy of your IELTS results.
5. Within a few days you should notice that your registered courses (Navigate to https://my.ust.hk/ -> click "Student Center" -> click "enrollment shopping cart" -> scroll to the bottom) will have a dropped LANG1002 course. This is completely normal and signifies that your application is being processed.
6. Remember to register a Common Core course to substitute for the dropped LANG course! Most Year 1 Fall students have a 14 credit load and you will probably want to live an easier Year 2 Fall and afterwards with a lower credit load then 15. I chose PHYS1111 since I had a 5 in DSE Physics and fortunately a 2 in M2 so that I don't have to compete with NDS in MATH1013 and PHYS1112.
7. Within a few more days you will receive an email from crtran@ust.hk, e.g.

Dear student,
You could now check your SIS system for credit transfer result. Thank you.
Best Regards,
Kayla LAM
Academic Registry

8. Verify that your Credit Transfer report (Navigate to https://my.ust.hk/ -> click "Student Center" -> click "My Academics" -> click "View my transfer credit report") has 6 credits successfully transferred. (See attachment SuccessfulTransfer.png)
9. In addition to submitting the official documents by email, you must also bring them to the HKUST Academic Registry to have them scanned. To remind you, you will receive an email:

Dear student,

You may wish to note that we have processed your credit transfer based on the transcript/certificate provided by you via email or uploaded to the credit transfer system (for credit transfer with institution courses).

Please be reminded to present the official transcript/certificate to the Academic Registry (Room 1381, 1/F, Lift 17-18) for our verification by the end of November 2020. Please refer to our webpage (https://arr.ust.hk/reg/index.html) for the opening hours.

Should you have any difficulty in presenting the official documents by the specified deadline, please do not hesitate to contact us (email: crtran@ust.hk).

See course description here - http://cle.ust.hk/courses/lang1002a/

In this course, we were taught the skills needed in building up the complexity, a necessary component in academic writing. One of the most important skills is nominalization, which is basically the technique of converting long clauses into noun phrases to make the sentence more compact.

Another learning point is cohesion, which is basically what distinguishes an A-range essay from a B-range essay. Cohesion is related to whether our essay seems logically and literally smooth and fluent. Sometimes your essay is comprised of individual sentences which are structurally and grammatically correct, but just doesn't look smooth on the whole. If that's the case, most likely what your essay lacks is cohesion.

For those who are always stuck at level 5 in writing should particularly work on the cohesion of your writing because most likely it is what bars you from getting a 6 or even a 7. Once you've mastered how to make your essays coherent, you'll easily grab As in your other LANG and SOSC/HUMA essays afterward.

reviews.comment_content:
Focus on "academic-purpose" English, so you can deal with the English at the university level. It focuses on writing and speaking. You don't have to worried about reading and listening for the first semester (this 1002A course).

No need to be worried about surviving this course but rather just have fun and chill :)

reviews.comment_grading:
Read other reviews for the exact percentage for each task

Vocab Quiz:
The difficulty is okay. Remember to finish all VOLT exercises (retry all of them until you score 100%) before taking it because it helps A LOT. Though don't finish them blindly and focus on the usage of each vocabulary. If you want to score high, you have to understand when you can and should use which vocabulary. When taking the test, try to fit in with another vocabulary because sometimes you may not notice that those words fit into the blanks.

Essays:
I don't have much advice on that, just try to imitate the sample given and make sure you have a rigid sentence structure.

Speaking test:
Don't freak out, be well prepared. If you are bad at speaking, focus on the content of your speech.

Description:
LANG1002 is a task-based, integrated-skills, English language course developed for first year students. It is the first of two one-semester courses which students take in order to fulfill the Common Core English requirement. The course is designed to raise your language proficiency and equip you with the underlying competence - e.g. thinking critically, discussing and presenting ideas logically - necessary for you to succeed in English-medium study in tertiary education.

In this course you will develop your ability to use English to communicate appropriately and effectively. The thematic focus of the course provides context for tasks, most of which require small group collaboration and discussion. They are central to the course methodology. The course materials have been designed to present you with in-class challenges to your present language proficiency and communication skills, and the course assessment will help you to develop these further.
Both research and experience have indicated that the major academic language needs of students are in the areas of writing, speaking, vocabulary and extensive reading. The specific emphasis of LANG1002 is, therefore, on increasing your ability to:

write in a coherent, well-organised way;
speak fluently, clearly, and effectively in a variety of contexts;
use a range of complex language, where appropriate to the task;
extract key information quickly from written texts;
take charge of your own language learning, particularly with respect to increasing your vocabulary.

LANG1002 is a task-based, integrated-skills, English language course developed for first year students. It is the first of two one-semester courses which students take in order to fulfill the Common Core English requirement. The course is designed to raise your language proficiency and equip you with the underlying competence - e.g. thinking critically, discussing and presenting ideas logically - necessary for you to succeed in English-medium study in tertiary education.

In this course you will develop your ability to use English to communicate appropriately and effectively. The thematic focus of the course provides context for tasks, most of which require small group collaboration and discussion. They are central to the course methodology. The course materials have been designed to present you with in-class challenges to your present language proficiency and communication skills, and the course assessment will help you to develop these further.

Both research and experience have indicated that the major academic language needs of students are in the areas of writing, speaking, vocabulary and extensive reading. The specific emphasis of LANG1002 is, therefore, on increasing your ability to:

write in a coherent, well-organised way;
speak fluently, clearly, and effectively in a variety of contexts;
use a range of complex language, where appropriate to the task;
extract key information quickly from written texts;
take charge of your own language learning, particularly with respect to increasing your vocabulary.
The course is graded and carries three credits.

reviews.author: CyrusL
reviews.comment_content:
The content of this course revolves around the four graded tasks.

The first of them is a self-recorded speech to inspire possibility in younger students. The course starts off by discussing the meaning of "passion", then moves on to various literacy skills such as paraphrasing and story-telling.

The second and third are both written tasks and are closely related: a single paragraph about a past game-changing idea, and an expository essay on the same topic, respectively. A library workshop that teaches you how to cite sources is hosted at this stage. Even if you don't care about participation marks, I highly recommend you attend it to avoid plagiarism in your work.

The fourth task is a talk about your past game-changer which is presented in front of the class. Basically, all you have to do is convert your essay into a speech. Easier said than done. Fortunately, this course introduces many techniques that help engage your audience during your talk.

Have I mentioned that there is a textbook designed for this course that is mandatory to have? It covers pretty much all of the content used for this course, so make sure you have it as soon as the course starts!
reviews.comment_teaching: This was Dr. Wong's first (and hopefully not only) time teaching this course, so her tutoring was less monotonous compared to the rest. She developed her own teaching materials to supplement the textbook examples, and was more than happy to answer our enquiries. She was always in a cheerful mood, which lightened the atmosphere of our class.

reviews.comment_content: It covers not-so-interesting topics but the materials were quite useful to improve your overall English proficiency. The teaching content also depends a lot on your course instructor, if the instructor is experienced in teaching, he/she would design his/her own teaching and learning materials.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Rebecca was very good at teaching. She really recognised her students' strengths and weaknesses, and she's really good at pointing out rooms for improvement for each individual.

One of her practices that really improved her students' writing skills was to share a google documents in which students are free to write and make it as a medium for writing exercise. She read every single writing and gave a lot of inputs and useful comments.

She was also willing to open a one-on-one session to discuss about her students' performance and difficulties. I think she was one of the best LANG instructors.

(P.S.: my class was a relatively small class, with only 10 students in it, but she also taught another class with around 15 students)
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading given by Rebecca was quite generous, but it also depends on your own language proficiency. She treasured her students' effort a lot and as long as you are quite active in the class you would be fine.

The speaking assessment she conducted was very fair and she tried her best to make sure that every student could unleash their potential. She made some appreciating gestures towards the student being assessed, which was very encouraging.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload given by Rebecca was very light and I think she gave us a lot of freedom in doing it. She even gave us choice to improve some parts of our speaking or writing skills. She did not expect us to do everything in such a short time.

reviews.comment_workload:
3 vocabulary learning records,
2 assessed speaking tasks,
1 assessed writing task.

The vocabulary learning records are not difficult to do at all, but please make sure that you have included all the definitions to all the words, as some words may have multiple meanings.

The writing task is about a game-changer of your choice. The essay has to have 500-800 words, that is, in fact, not much. So you really need to make your content as concise as possible. Make sure to check your citations so that they are all correct. You can earn a bonus point for that.

The first speaking task has to be videotaped and be submitted on canvas. So you should probably record a few times and see which one you think is the best before you hand in your work.

The second speaking task has to be done in class in front of your classmates. It is about a game-changer, most likely the one you have written in your writing task.
